Foreign policy.
Under Tito, Yugoslavia adopted a policy of nonalignment in the Cold War. It developed close relations with developing countries by having a leading role in the <a href="Non-Aligned%20Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, as well as maintaining cordial relations with the United States and Western European countries. Stalin considered Tito a traitor and openly offered condemnation towards him. Yugoslavia provided major assistance to anti-colonialist movements in the Third World. The Yugoslav delegation was the first to bring the demands of the Algerian <a href="National%20Liberation%20Front%20%28Algeria%29">National Liberation Front</a> to the United Nations. In January 1958, the French navy boarded the Slovenija cargo ship off <a href="Oran">Oran</a>, whose holds were filled with weapons for the insurgents. Diplomat Danilo Milic explained that "Tito and the leading nucleus of the <a href="League%20of%20Communists%20of%20Yugoslavia">League of Communists of Yugoslavia</a> really saw in the Third World's liberation struggles a replica of their own struggle against the fascist occupants. They vibrated to the rhythm of the advances or setbacks of the FLN or <a href="Vietcong">Vietcong</a>." Thousands of Yugoslav cooperants travelled to <a href="Guinea">Guinea</a> after its decolonisation and as the French government tried to destabilise the country. Tito also helped the liberation movements of the Portuguese colonies. He saw the murder of <a href="Patrice%20Lumumba">Patrice Lumumba</a> in 1961 as the "greatest crime in contemporary history". The country's military schools hosted activists from <a href="Swapo">Swapo</a> (Namibia) and the <a href="Pan%20Africanist%20Congress%20of%20Azania">Pan Africanist Congress of Azania</a> (South Africa). In 1980, the secret services of South Africa and Argentina planned to bring 1,500 anti-communist guerrillas to Yugoslavia. The operation was aimed at overthrowing Tito and was planned during the Olympic Games period so that the Soviets would be too busy to react. The operation was finally abandoned due to Tito's death and while the Yugoslav armed forces raised their alert level. On 1 January 1967, Yugoslavia was the first Communist country to open its borders to all foreign visitors and abolish visa requirements. In the same year, Tito became active in promoting a peaceful resolution of the <a href="Arab%E2%80%93Israeli%20conflict">Arab–Israeli conflict</a>. His plan called for Arab countries to recognize the State of Israel in exchange for Israel returning territories it had gained. The Arab countries rejected his land for peace concept. However, that same year, Yugoslavia no longer recognized Israel. In 1968, following the <a href="Soviet%20invasion%20of%20Czechoslovakia">Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia</a>, Tito added an additional defense line to Yugoslavia's borders with the Warsaw Pact countries. Later in 1968, Tito then offered Czechoslovak leader <a href="Alexander%20Dub%C4%8Dek">Alexander Dubček</a> that he would fly to <a href="Prague">Prague</a> on three hours notice if Dubček needed help in facing down the Soviet Union which was occupying <a href="Czechoslovak%20Socialist%20Republic">Czechoslovakia</a> at the time. Yugoslavia had mixed relations towards <a href="Enver%20Hoxha">Enver Hoxha</a>'s <a href="People%27s%20Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Albania">Albania</a>. Initially Yugoslav-Albanian relations were forthcoming, as Albania adopted a common market with Yugoslavia and required the teaching of Serbo-Croatian to students in high schools. At this time, the concept of creating a Balkan Federation was being discussed between Yugoslavia, Albania, and Bulgaria. Albania at this time was heavily dependent on economic support of Yugoslavia to fund its initially weak infrastructure. Trouble between Yugoslavia and Albania began when Albanians began to complain that Yugoslavia was paying too little for Albania's natural resources. Afterward, relations between Yugoslavia and Albania worsened. From 1948 onward, the Soviet Union backed Albania in opposition to Yugoslavia. On the issue of Albanian-dominated Kosovo, Yugoslavia and Albania both attempted to neutralize the threat of nationalist conflict, Hoxha opposed <a href="Albanian%20nationalism">Albanian nationalism</a>, as he officially believed in the <a href="world%20communist">world communist</a> ideal of international brotherhood of all people, though on a few occasions in the 1980s he made inflammatory speeches in support of Albanians in Kosovo against the Yugoslav government, when public sentiment in Albania was firmly in support of Kosovo's Albanians.
Economy.
Despite their common origins, the socialist economy of Yugoslavia was much different from the <a href="economy%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">economy of the Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="economies%20of%20the%20Eastern%20Bloc">economies of the Eastern Bloc</a>, especially after the <a href="Yugoslav%E2%80%93Soviet%20break-up">Yugoslav–Soviet break-up</a> of 1948. Though they were <a href="state-owned%20enterprise">state-owned enterprise</a>s, Yugoslav companies were nominally collectively managed by the employees themselves through <a href="workers%27%20self-management">workers' self-management</a>, albeit with state oversight dictating wage bills and the hiring and firing of managers The occupation and liberation struggle in World War II left Yugoslavia's infrastructure devastated. Even the most developed parts of the country were largely rural, and the little industry the country had was largely damaged or destroyed. Unemployment was a chronic problem for Yugoslavia: the unemployment rates were amongst the highest in Europe during its existence and they did not reach critical levels before the 1980s only due to the safety valve provided by sending one million guest workers yearly to advanced industrialized countries in <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a>. The departure of Yugoslavs seeking work began in the 1950s, when individuals began slipping across the border illegally. In the mid-1960s, Yugoslavia lifted emigration restrictions and the number of emigrants increased rapidly, especially to <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. By the early 1970s, 20% of the country's labor force or 1.1 million workers were employed abroad. This was also a source of capital and foreign currency for Yugoslavia.
Due to Yugoslavia's neutrality and its leading role in the <a href="Non-Aligned%20Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, Yugoslav companies exported to both Western and Eastern markets. Yugoslav companies carried out construction of numerous major infrastructural and industrial projects in Africa, Europe and Asia. In the 1970s, the economy was reorganized according to <a href="Edvard%20Kardelj">Edvard Kardelj</a>'s theory of associated labor, in which the right to decision-making and a share in profits of worker-run <a href="cooperative">cooperative</a>s is based on the investment of labour. All companies were transformed into "organizations of associated labor". The smallest, "basic organizations of associated labor", roughly corresponded to a small company or a department in a large company. These were organized into "enterprises" which in turn associated into "composite organizations of associated labor", which could be large companies or even whole-industry branches in a certain area. Most executive decision-making was based in <a href="Organization">enterprises</a>, so that these continued to <a href="Competition">compete</a> to an extent, even when they were part of a same composite organization.
In practice, the appointment of managers and the strategic policies of composite organizations were, depending on their size and importance, often subject to political and personal influence-peddling. In order to give all employees the same access to decision-making, the "basic organisations of associated labor" were also applied to public services, including health and education. The basic organizations were usually made up of no more than a few dozen people and had their own <a href="workers%27%20councils">workers' councils</a>, whose assent was needed for strategic decisions and appointment of managers in enterprises or public institutions.
The results of these reforms however were not satisfactory. There have been rampant wage-price inflations, substantial rundown of capital plant and consumer shortages, while the income gap between the poorer Southern and the relatively affluent Northern regions of the country remained. The self-management system stimulated the inflationary economy that was needed to support it. Large state-owned enterprises operated as monopolists with unrestricted access to capital that was shared according to political criteria. The <a href="oil%20crisis%20of%201973">oil crisis of 1973</a> magnified the economic problems, which the government tried to solve with extensive foreign borrowing. Although such actions resulted in a reasonable rate of growth for a few years (GNP grew at 5.1% yearly), such growth was unsustainable since the rate of foreign borrowing grew at an annual rate of 20%.
Life conditions deteriorated in Yugoslavia in the 1980s, and were reflected in soaring unemployment rates and inflation. In the late 1980s, the unemployment rate in Yugoslavia was over 17%, with another 20% <a href="Underemployment">underemployed</a>; with 60% of the unemployed under the age of 25. Real net personal income declined by 19.5%. The nominal GDP per capita of Yugoslavia at current prices in US dollars was at $3,549 in 1990. The central government tried to reform the self-management system and create an open market economy with considerable state ownership of major industrial factories, but <a href="Strike%20action">strikes</a> in major plants and <a href="hyperinflation%20in%20the%20Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">hyperinflation held back progress</a>.
The <a href="Yugoslav%20wars">Yugoslav wars</a> and consequent loss of market, as well as mismanagement and/or non-transparent privatization, brought further economic trouble for all the former republics of Yugoslavia in the 1990s.
The Yugoslav currency was the <a href="Yugoslav%20dinar">Yugoslav dinar</a>.

Transportation.
Air transport.
While being a Communist country, after the <a href="Tito%E2%80%93Stalin%20split">Tito–Stalin split</a> Yugoslavia initiated a period of military neutrality and Non-Alignment. Its airlines were supplied by both the East and the West. <a href="JAT%20Airways">JAT Yugoslav Airlines</a> became the flag carrier by absorbing the previous company <a href="Aeroput">Aeroput</a>. During its existence it grew to become one of the leading airlines in Europe both by fleet and destinations. Its fleet included most of the Western-built aircraft, and destinations included all 5 continents. By the 1970s more airlines were created, namely <a href="Aviogenex">Aviogenex</a>, <a href="Adria%20Airways">Adria Airways</a> and <a href="Pan%20Adria%20Airways">Pan Adria Airways</a> mostly focused in the growing tourist industry. The capital <a href="Belgrade%20Nikola%20Tesla%20Airport">Belgrade Airport</a> became the regional hub offering flights, either by the national airline JAT, or by other airlines, to all important destinations worldwide. Aside from Belgrade, most international flights would include a stop in <a href="Zagreb%20Airport">Zagreb Airport</a>, the second national airport in terms of passenger and cargo capacity; the two became the sole international hubs. All secondary airports such as the ones in <a href="Sarajevo%20Airport">Sarajevo</a>, <a href="Skopje%20Airport%20-">Skopje</a>, <a href="Split%20Airport">Split</a> or <a href="Ljubljana%20Airport">Ljubljana</a> were directly linked to international flights through either Belgrade or Zagreb, while a number of tourism-oriented destinations were developed, such as <a href="Dubrovnik%20Airport">Dubrovnik</a>, <a href="Rijeka%20Airport">Rijeka</a>, <a href="Ohrid%20Airport">Ohrid</a>, <a href="Tivat%20Airport">Tivat</a> and others.
Railways.
The railway system in Yugoslavia was operated by the <a href="Yugoslav%20Railways">Yugoslav Railways</a>. Much of the infrastructure was inherited from the pre-WWII period, and SFRY period was marked by the extension and electrification of the rails. Electric and diesel locomotives were introduced in number from the 1960s onwards. Much of the early rolling stock were European produced, while with time were being replaced with domestically built locomotives, mostly from <a href="KON%C4%8CAR%20Group">Rade Končar</a> and carriages, mostly from GOŠA. The main two projects during SFRY period were electrification of the <a href="Zagreb%E2%80%93Belgrade%20railway">Zagreb–Belgrade railway</a>, and the building of the highly challenging <a href="Belgrade%E2%80%93Bar%20railway">Belgrade–Bar railway</a>. Yugoslav railways operated a number of international services, such as the <a href="Orient%20Express">Orient Express</a>.
Roads.
The core of the road network in Yugoslavia was the <a href="Brotherhood%20and%20Unity%20Highway">Brotherhood and Unity Highway</a> which was a highway that stretched over , from the <a href="Austria">Austria</a>n border at <a href="Rate%C4%8De">Rateče</a> near <a href="Kranjska%20Gora">Kranjska Gora</a> in the northwest via <a href="Ljubljana">Ljubljana</a>, <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>, <a href="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> and <a href="Skopje">Skopje</a> to <a href="Gevgelija">Gevgelija</a> on the <a href="Greece">Greek</a> border in the southeast. It was the main modern highway in the country, connecting four constituent republics. It was the pioneer highway in Central-Eastern Europe, and the main link between Central and Western Europe with South-Eastern Europe and Middle East. Construction began on the initiative of President Tito. The first section between Zagreb and Belgrade was built with the effort of the <a href="Yugoslav%20People%27s%20Army">Yugoslav People's Army</a> and volunteer <a href="Youth%20work%20actions">Youth Work Actions</a> and was opened in 1950. The section between Ljubljana and Zagreb was built by 54,000 volunteers in less than eight months in 1958.
Maritime and river transportation.
With its extensive coast in the <a href="Adriatic%20sea">Adriatic sea</a>, Yugoslavia included several large ports such as Split, Rijeka, Zadar or Pula. Ferries providing passenger service were established linking Yugoslav ports with several ports in Italy and Greece. Regarding rivers, the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> was navigable throughout its entire course in Yugoslavia, linking the ports of Belgrade, Novi Sad, and Vukovar with Central Europe and the Black sea. Long stretches of rivers <a href="Sava">Sava</a>, <a href="Drava">Drava</a> and <a href="Tisza">Tisza</a> were also navigable.
Urban.
Accompanying the high urban growth, urban transportation in Yugoslavia was significantly developed in all republic capitals and major cities. Urban bus networks existed in all cities, while many also included trolleybuses and trams. Despite having been planned for decades, <a href="Belgrade%20Metro">Belgrade Metro</a> never materialised, and Belgrade became the major capital in Europe not to have metro. Instead, Belgrade city authorities opted for the development of urban rail transport, <a href="Beovoz">Beovoz</a>, and an extensive tram, bus and trolley network.

Communications.
Radio and television.
One of the founding members of the <a href="European%20Broadcasting%20Union">European Broadcasting Union</a>, <a href="Yugoslav%20Radio%20Television">Yugoslav Radio Television</a>, known as JRT, was the national <a href="public%20broadcasting">public broadcasting</a> system in Yugoslavia. It consisted of eight <a href="subnational%20administrative%20division">subnational</a> radio and television broadcast centers with each one headquartered in one of the six constituent republics and two autonomous provinces. Each television center created its own programming independently, and some of them operated several channels. This subnational broadcasting centers became public broadcasters of the newly independent states, with altered names, after the break-up of Yugoslavia. <a href="Croatian%20Radiotelevision">Zagreb Radio</a> started broadcasting on 15 May 1926, and was the first public broadcasting facility in Southeast Europe. On the 30th anniversary of the establishment of Zagreb Radio station, on 15 May 1956, the first television programme was broadcast. This was the first TV station in Yugoslavia and would later become a color station in 1972. <a href="Radio%20Television%20of%20Serbia">RT Belgrade</a> and <a href="Radiotelevizija%20Slovenija">RT Ljubljana</a> started broadcasting its television programmes two years later, in 1958.
Geography.
Like the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a> that preceded it, the SFRY bordered Italy and Austria to the northwest, Hungary to the northeast, Romania and Bulgaria to the east, Greece to the south, Albania to the southwest, and the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> to the west. During the socialist period it was common for history and geography teachers to teach their students that Yugoslavia bordered with "brigama", a Serbo-Croatian word meaning "worries" and that was an <a href="acronym">acronym</a> of the initials of all the countries Yugoslavia bordered with, transformed into a <a href="mnemonic">mnemonic</a> principle used for both, easy learning and ironic reminder of the difficult relations Yugoslav people had with its neighbors in the past. The most significant change to the borders of the SFRY occurred in 1954, when the adjacent <a href="Free%20Territory%20of%20Trieste">Free Territory of Trieste</a> was dissolved by the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Osimo">Treaty of Osimo</a>. The Yugoslav Zone B, which covered , became part of the SFRY. Zone B was already occupied by the Yugoslav National Army. In 1989 the country bordered Italy and the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> to the west; Austria and <a href="Hungarian%20People%27s%20Republic">Hungary</a> to the north; <a href="Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the east; Greece to the south and <a href="People%27s%20Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Albania">Albania</a> to the south-west. In 1991, the SFRY's territory disintegrated as the independent states of <a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, Croatia, <a href="Republic%20of%20Macedonia">Macedonia</a>, and <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> separated from it, though the Yugoslav military controlled parts of Croatia and Bosnia prior to the state's dissolution. By 1992, only the republics of <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> remained committed to union, and formed the <a href="Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a> (FRY) in that year.
Demographics.
Ethnic groups.
The SFRY recognised "nations" "(narodi)" and "nationalities" "(narodnosti)" separately; the former included the constituent <a href="South%20Slavs">South Slavic</a> peoples (<a href="Croats">Croats</a>, <a href="Macedonians%20%28ethnic%20group%29">Macedonians</a>, <a href="Montenegrins">Montenegrins</a>, <a href="Muslims%20%28ethnic%20group%29">Muslims</a> (from 1971), <a href="Serbs">Serbs</a> and <a href="Slovenes">Slovenes</a>), while the latter included other <a href="Slavs">Slavic</a> and non-Slavic ethnic groups such as <a href="Slovaks">Slovaks</a>, <a href="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a>, <a href="Rusyns">Rusyns</a> and <a href="Czechs">Czechs</a> (Slavic); or <a href="Albanians">Albanians</a>, <a href="Hungarians">Hungarians</a>, <a href="Romani%20people">Romani</a>, <a href="Turkish%20people">Turks</a>, <a href="Romanians">Romanians</a>, <a href="Vlachs">Vlachs</a>, <a href="Italians">Italians</a>, and <a href="Germans">Germans</a> (non-Slavic). In total, about 26 known sizeable ethnic groups were known to live in Yugoslavia. There was also a <a href="Yugoslavs">Yugoslav</a> ethnic designation, for the people who wanted to identify with the entire country, including people who were born to parents in mixed marriages.
Languages.
The population of Yugoslavia spoke mainly three languages: <a href="Serbo-Croatian%20language">Serbo-Croatian</a>, <a href="Slovene%20language">Slovene</a> and <a href="Macedonian%20language">Macedonian</a>. Serbo-Croatian was spoken by the populations in the federated republics of <a href="SR%20Serbia">SR Serbia</a>, <a href="SR%20Croatia">SR Croatia</a>, <a href="SR%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">SR Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, and <a href="SR%20Montenegro">SR Montenegro</a> – a total of 12,390,000 people by the late 1980s. Slovene was spoken by approximately 2,000,000 inhabitants of <a href="SR%20Slovenia">SR Slovenia</a>, while Macedonian was spoken by 1,210,000 inhabitants of SR Macedonia. National minorities used their own languages as well, with 506,000 speaking <a href="Hungarian%20language">Hungarian</a> (primarily in <a href="SAP%20Vojvodina">SAP Vojvodina</a>), and 2,000,000 persons speaking <a href="Albanian%20language">Albanian</a> in SR Serbia (primarily in <a href="SAP%20Kosovo">SAP Kosovo</a>), SR Macedonia and SR Montenegro. <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a>, <a href="Romanian%20language">Romanian</a> (primarily in SAP Vojvodina), and <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> (primarily in <a href="Istria">Istria</a> and parts of <a href="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>) were also spoken to a lesser extent. The Yugoslav Albanians, almost exclusively <a href="Ghegs">Ghegs</a>, chose to use the unified standard language of Albania predominantly based on <a href="Tosk%20Albanian">Tosk Albanian</a> (a different dialect), for political reasons. The three main languages all belong to the <a href="South%20Slavic%20languages">South Slavic</a> language group and are thus similar, allowing most people from different areas to understand each other. Intellectuals were mostly acquainted with all three languages, while people of more modest means from SR Slovenia and SR Macedonia were provided an opportunity to learn Serbo-Croatian during the compulsory service in the federal military. Serbo-Croatian itself is made-up of three dialects, <a href="Shtokavian">Shtokavian</a>, <a href="Kajkavian">Kajkavian</a>, and <a href="Chakavian">Chakavian</a>, with Shtokavian used as the standard official dialect of the language. Official Serbo-Croatian (Shtokavian), was divided into two similar variants, the Croatian (Western) variant and Serbian (Eastern) variant, with minor <a href="Differences%20between%20standard%20Bosnian%2C%20Croatian%20and%20Serbian">differences</a> telling the two apart. Two alphabets used in Yugoslavia were: the <a href="Latin%20alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> and the <a href="Cyrillic%20script">Cyrillic script</a>. Both alphabets were modified for use by Serbo-Croatian in the 19th century, thus the Serbo-Croatian Latin alphabet is more closely known as <a href="Gaj%27s%20Latin%20alphabet">Gaj's Latin alphabet</a>, while Cyrillic is referred to as the <a href="Serbian%20Cyrillic%20alphabet">Serbian Cyrillic alphabet</a>. Serbo-Croatian uses both alphabets, Slovene uses only the Latin alphabet, and Macedonian uses only the Cyrillic alphabet. Bosnian and Croatian variants of the language used exclusively Latin, while the Serbian variant used both Latin and Cyrillic.
Emigration.
The small or negative population growth in the former Yugoslavia reflected a high level of <a href="emigration">emigration</a>. Even before the breakup of the country, during the 1960s and 1970s, Yugoslavia was one of the most important "sending societies" of international migration. An important receiving society was <a href="Immigration%20from%20the%20former%20Yugoslavia%20to%20Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, target of an estimated total of 500,000 migrants, who now account for more than 6% of total Swiss population. Similar numbers emigrated to Germany, Austria, Australia, Sweden and to North America.
Military.
The armed forces of SFR Yugoslavia consisted of the <a href="Yugoslav%20People%27s%20Army">Yugoslav People's Army</a> ("Jugoslovenska narodna armija", JNA), Territorial Defense (TO), Civil Defense (CZ) and "<a href="Militsiya">Milicija</a>" (police) in wartime. Socialist Yugoslavia maintained a strong military force. JNA was the main organization of the military forces plus the remnacents of the royal Yugoslav army, and was composed of the ground army, navy and aviation. Militarily, Yugoslavia had a policy of self-sufficiency. Due to its policy of neutrality and non-alignment, efforts were made to develop the country's military industry to provide the military with all its needs, and even for export. Most of its military equipment and pieces were domestically produced, while some was imported both from the East and the West. The regular army mostly originated from the <a href="Yugoslav%20Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a> of <a href="World%20War%20II%20in%20Yugoslavia">World War II</a>. Yugoslavia had a thriving <a href="arms%20industry">arms industry</a> and exported to nations such as <a href="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>, and <a href="Myanmar">Burma</a>, among others (including a number of staunchly anti-communist regimes like Guatemala). Yugoslav companies like <a href="Zastava%20Arms">Zastava Arms</a> produced <a href="USSR">Soviet</a>-designed weaponry under license as well as creating weaponry from scratch, ranging from police pistols to airplanes. <a href="SOKO">SOKO</a> was an example of a successful military aircraft design by Yugoslavia before the <a href="Yugoslav%20wars">Yugoslav wars</a>. Beside the federal army, each of the six republics had their own respective Territorial Defense Forces. They were a national guard of sorts, established in the frame of a new <a href="military%20doctrine">military doctrine</a> called "General Popular Defense" as an answer to the brutal end of the <a href="Prague%20Spring">Prague Spring</a> by the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> in <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> in 1968. It was organized on republic, autonomous province, municipality and local community levels. As <a href="Breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia splintered</a>, the army factionalized along ethnic lines, and by 1991–92 <a href="Serbs">Serbs</a> made up almost the entire army as the separating states formed their own.
Education.

Arts.
Prior to the collapse of Yugoslavia in the 1990s, Yugoslavia had a modern multicultural society. Characteristic attention was based on the concept of brotherhood and unity and the memory of the Communist <a href="Yugoslav%20Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a>' victory against fascists and nationalists as the rebirth of the Yugoslav people, although all forms of art flourished freely unlike in other socialist counties. In the SFRY the history of Yugoslavia during World War II was omnipresent, and was portrayed as a struggle not only between Yugoslavia and the Axis Powers, but as a struggle between good and evil within Yugoslavia with the multiethnic Yugoslav Partisans were represented as the "good" Yugoslavs fighting against manipulated "evil" Yugoslavs – the Croatian <a href="Usta%C5%A1e">Ustaše</a> and Serbian <a href="Chetniks">Chetniks</a>. The SFRY was presented to its people as the leader of the non-aligned movement and that the SFRY was dedicated to creating a just, harmonious, <a href="Marxist">Marxist</a> world.
Artists from different ethnicities in the country were popular amongst other ethnicities, and the film industry in Yugoslavia avoided nationalist overtones until the 1990s. Unlike in other socialist societies, Yugoslavia was considered tolerant to a popular and classical art as long as it was not overly critical of the ruling regime, which made Yugoslavia appear to be a free country despite its one-party regime structure.
Literature.
Some of the most prominent Yugoslav writers were the <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20for%20Literature">Nobel Prize for Literature</a> laureate <a href="Ivo%20Andri%C4%87">Ivo Andrić</a>, <a href="Miroslav%20Krle%C5%BEa">Miroslav Krleža</a>, <a href="Me%C5%A1a%20Selimovi%C4%87">Meša Selimović</a>, <a href="Branko%20%C4%86opi%C4%87">Branko Ćopić</a>, <a href="Mak%20Dizdar">Mak Dizdar</a> and others.
Graphic arts.
Notable painters included: <a href="%C4%90or%C4%91e%20Andrejevi%C4%87%20Kun">Đorđe Andrejević Kun</a>, <a href="Petar%20Lubarda">Petar Lubarda</a>, <a href="Mersad%20Berber">Mersad Berber</a>, <a href="Mili%C4%87%20od%20Ma%C4%8Dve">Milić od Mačve</a> and others. Prominent sculptor was <a href="Antun%20Augustin%C4%8Di%C4%87">Antun Augustinčić</a> who made a monument standing in front of the <a href="United%20Nations%20Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a> in New York City.

Music.
Traditional music.
Prominent <a href="traditional%20music">traditional music</a> artists were the award-winning <a href="Tanec">Tanec</a> ensemble, the <a href="Romani%20music">Gypsy music</a> performer <a href="Esma%20Red%C5%BEepova">Esma Redžepova</a> and others. A very popular genre in Yugoslavia, also exported to other neighboring countries, and also popular among the Yugoslav emigration worldwide, was the <a href="Narodna%20muzika">Narodna muzika</a>. The Slovenian most popular folk music was played by Avsenik brothers (Ansambel bratov Avsenik) and Lojze Slak.The <a href="Serbian%20folk%20music">folk music</a> emerged in force during the 1970s and 1980s, and by the 1980s and 1990s the so-called novokomponovana muzika style appeared and gave place to controversial <a href="turbo-folk">turbo-folk</a> style. <a href="Lepa%20Brena">Lepa Brena</a> in the 1980s become the most popular singer of the Yugoslavia, and a top-selling female recording artist with more than 40 million records sold. Folk performers enjoyed great popularity and became constant presence in the tabloids and media. Yugoslav music scene in its diverse genres became known internationally, from traditional folklor music being appreciated worldwide, through rock-pop music being appreciated in Eastern, and lesser extent, Western Europe, to turbo-folk music being widely exported to neighboring countries.
Classical music.
The pianist <a href="Ivo%20Pogoreli%C4%87">Ivo Pogorelić</a> and the violinist <a href="Stefan%20Milenkovi%C4%87">Stefan Milenković</a> were internationally acclaimed classical music performers, while <a href="Jakov%20Gotovac">Jakov Gotovac</a> was a prominent composer and a conductor.
Popular music.
As a member of the <a href="Non-Aligned%20Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, Yugoslavia was far more open to Western culture than other socialist countries, and the western-influenced <a href="popular%20music">popular music</a> was socially accepted and well covered in the media, which included numerous concerts, music magazines, radio and TV shows. The <a href="Popular%20music%20in%20the%20Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslav rock scene</a>, which emerged in the late 1950s, generally followed Western European and American trends with local and Eastern European influence. The most notable Yugoslav rock acts included <a href="Atomsko%20Skloni%C5%A1te">Atomsko Sklonište</a>, <a href="Azra">Azra</a>, <a href="Bajaga%20i%20Instruktori">Bajaga i Instruktori</a>, <a href="%C4%90or%C4%91e%20Bala%C5%A1evi%C4%87">Đorđe Balašević</a>, <a href="Bijelo%20Dugme">Bijelo Dugme</a>, <a href="Buldo%C5%BEer">Buldožer</a>, <a href="Crvena%20Jabuka">Crvena Jabuka</a>, <a href="Zdravko%20%C4%8Coli%C4%87">Zdravko Čolić</a>, <a href="Divlje%20Jagode">Divlje Jagode</a>, <a href="Ekatarina%20Velika">Ekatarina Velika</a>, <a href="Elektri%C4%8Dni%20Orgazam">Električni Orgazam</a>, <a href="Film%20%28band%29">Film</a>, <a href="Galija">Galija</a>, <a href="Haustor">Haustor</a>, <a href="Idoli">Idoli</a>, <a href="Indexi">Indexi</a>, <a href="Korni%20Grupa">Korni Grupa</a>, <a href="KUD%20Idijoti">KUD Idijoti</a>, <a href="Laboratorija%20Zvuka">Laboratorija Zvuka</a>, <a href="La%C4%8Dni%20Franz">Lačni Franz</a>, <a href="Laibach%20%28band%29">Laibach</a>, <a href="Leb%20i%20Sol">Leb i Sol</a>, <a href="Josipa%20Lisac">Josipa Lisac</a>, <a href="Pankrti">Pankrti</a>, <a href="Paraf">Paraf</a>, <a href="Parni%20Valjak">Parni Valjak</a>, <a href="Partibrejkers">Partibrejkers</a>, <a href="Pekin%C5%A1ka%20Patka">Pekinška Patka</a>, <a href="Plavi%20Orkestar">Plavi Orkestar</a>, <a href="Prljavo%20Kazali%C5%A1te">Prljavo Kazalište</a>, <a href="Psihomodo%20Pop">Psihomodo Pop</a>, <a href="Riblja%20%C4%8Corba">Riblja Čorba</a>, <a href="September%20%28band%29">September</a>, <a href="Smak">Smak</a>, <a href="%C5%A0arlo%20Akrobata">Šarlo Akrobata</a>, <a href="Time%20%28rock%20band%29">Time</a>, <a href="YU%20Grupa">YU Grupa</a>, <a href="Zabranjeno%20Pu%C5%A1enje">Zabranjeno Pušenje</a>, <a href="Paraf">Paraf</a> and others. It was the only Communist country that took part in the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a>, starting in <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%201961">1961</a>, even before some <a href="Western%20Bloc">Western</a> nations, with the group <a href="Riva%20%28music%20group%29">Riva</a> winning in <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%201989">1989</a>.
Architectural heritage.
Although Yugoslav cities and towns architecturally resembled and followed the styles of Central and Southeastern Europe, what became most characteristic of the SFRY period was the creation of a modernist or brutalist style architecture buildings and neighborhoods. Yugoslav cities expanded greatly during this period and the government often opted for the creation of modernist planned neighborhoods to accommodate the growing working middle-class. Such typical examples are the <a href="Novi%20Beograd">Novi Beograd</a> and <a href="Novi%20Zagreb">Novi Zagreb</a> neighborhoods in two major cities.
Sports.
FPR/SFR Yugoslavia developed a strong athletic sports community, notably in team sports such as association football, basketball, handball, water polo, and volleyball.
Football.
The country's biggest footballing achievement came on the club level with <a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star Belgrade</a> winning the <a href="1990%E2%80%9391%20European%20Cup">1990–91 European Cup</a>, beating <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a> in the <a href="1991%20European%20Cup%20Final">final</a> played on 29 May 1991. Later that year, they became world club champions by beating <a href="Colo-Colo">Colo-Colo</a> 3–0 in the <a href="1991%20Intercontinental%20Cup">Intercontinental Cup</a>.
Previously, Red Star had reached the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20UEFA%20Cup">1978–79 UEFA Cup</a> <a href="Two-legged%20tie">two-legged</a> <a href="1979%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">final</a>, while their Belgrade <a href="Ve%C4%8Diti%20derbi">cross-town rivals</a> <a href="FK%20Partizan">Partizan</a> had been the <a href="1965%E2%80%9366%20European%20Cup">1965–66 European Cup</a> <a href="1966%20European%20Cup%20Final">finalists</a>. <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> <a href="1967%20Inter-Cities%20Fairs%20Cup%20Final">won</a> the <a href="1966%E2%80%9367%20Inter-Cities%20Fairs%20Cup">1966–67 Inter-Cities Fairs Cup</a>. Furthermore, <a href="NK%20%C4%8Celik%20Zenica">Čelik Zenica</a> (twice), Red Star Belgrade, <a href="FK%20Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>, Partizan, <a href="NK%20Iskra%20Bugojno">Iskra Bugojno</a>, and <a href="FK%20Borac%20Banja%20Luka">Borac Banja Luka</a> won the <a href="Mitropa%20Cup">Mitropa Cup</a>; while <a href="FK%20Vele%C5%BE%20Mostar">Velež Mostar</a>, <a href="HNK%20Rijeka">Rijeka</a>, Dinamo Zagreb, and <a href="FK%20Radni%C4%8Dki%20Ni%C5%A1">Radnički Niš</a>, each won the <a href="Balkans%20Cup">Balkans Cup</a>.
On the national team level, <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20football%20team">FPR/SFR Yugoslavia</a> qualified for seven <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>s, the best result coming in <a href="1962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1962</a> in <a href="Chile">Chile</a> with a 4th-place finish (equalizing the Kingdom of Yugoslavia achievement from <a href="1930%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1930</a>). The country also played in four <a href="UEFA%20European%20Football%20Championship">European Championships</a>. The best results came in 1960 and 1968 when the team lost in the finals—in <a href="1960%20European%20Nations%27%20Cup%20Final">1960</a> to Soviet Union and in <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201968%20Final">1968</a> to Italy. Yugoslavia was also the first non-Western European country to host a European Championship, <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201976">UEFA Euro 1976</a>.
Additionally, the <a href="Yugoslavia%20Olympic%20football%20team">Yugoslav Olympic team</a> won gold at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201960%20Summer%20Olympics">1960 Olympics</a> in Rome, having previously won silver at the three preceding Olympic Games —<a href="Football%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948</a> in London, <a href="Football%20at%20the%201952%20Summer%20Olympics">1952</a> in Helsinki, and <a href="Association%20football%20at%20the%201956%20Summer%20Olympics">1956</a> in Melbourne. The team additionally won bronze in <a href="Football%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984</a> in Los Angeles.
In the youth category, <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Yugoslavia under-20 team</a> qualified for just two <a href="FIFA%20World%20Youth%20Championship">FIFA World Youth Championship</a>s, but won in <a href="1987%20FIFA%20World%20Youth%20Championship">1987</a> in Chile while the <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Yugoslav under-21 team</a> qualified for four <a href="UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship</a>s winning the inaugural edition in <a href="1978%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">1978</a> and coming runners-up in <a href="1990%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">1990</a>.
On the individual player front, Yugoslavia produced some notable performers on the world stage; such as <a href="Rajko%20Miti%C4%87">Rajko Mitić</a>, <a href="Stjepan%20Bobek">Stjepan Bobek</a>, <a href="Bernard%20Vukas">Bernard Vukas</a>, <a href="Vladimir%20Beara">Vladimir Beara</a>, <a href="Dragoslav%20%C5%A0ekularac">Dragoslav Šekularac</a>, <a href="Milan%20Gali%C4%87">Milan Galić</a>, <a href="Josip%20Skoblar">Josip Skoblar</a>, <a href="Ivan%20%C4%86urkovi%C4%87">Ivan Ćurković</a>, <a href="Velibor%20Vasovi%C4%87">Velibor Vasović</a>, <a href="Dragan%20D%C5%BEaji%C4%87">Dragan Džajić</a>, <a href="Safet%20Su%C5%A1i%C4%87">Safet Sušić</a>, <a href="Dragan%20Stojkovi%C4%87">Dragan Stojković</a>, <a href="Dejan%20Savi%C4%87evi%C4%87">Dejan Savićević</a>, <a href="Darko%20Pan%C4%8Dev">Darko Pančev</a>, <a href="Robert%20Prosine%C4%8Dki">Robert Prosinečki</a>, and others.
Basketball.
Unlike football which inherited a lot of its infrastructure and know-how from the pre-World War II Kingdom of Yugoslavia, basketball had very little prior heritage. The sport was thus nurtured and developed from scratch within the Communist Yugoslavia through individual enthusiasts such as <a href="Neboj%C5%A1a%20Popovi%C4%87">Nebojša Popović</a>, <a href="Borislav%20Stankovi%C4%87">Bora Stanković</a>, <a href="Radomir%20%C5%A0aper">Radomir Šaper</a>, <a href="Aleksandar%20Nikoli%C4%87">Aca Nikolić</a>, and <a href="Ranko%20%C5%BDeravica">Ranko Žeravica</a>. Though a member of <a href="FIBA">FIBA</a> since 1936, the national team didn't qualify for a major competition until after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. In 1948, the country's umbrella basketball association, <a href="Basketball%20Federation%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslav Basketball Federation</a> (KSJ), was established.
Following its major competition debut at <a href="EuroBasket%201947">EuroBasket 1947</a>, <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20basketball%20team">Yugoslav national team</a> didn't take long to become a contender on world stage with the first medal, a silver, coming at <a href="EuroBasket%201961">EuroBasket 1961</a>. The country's most notable results were winning three <a href="FIBA%20World%20Championship">FIBA World Championship</a>s (in <a href="1970%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1970</a>, <a href="1978%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1978</a>, and <a href="1990%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">1990</a>), a gold medal at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Olympics</a> in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, in addition to five <a href="Eurobasket">European Championships</a> (three of them consecutively <a href="EuroBasket%201973">1973</a>, <a href="EuroBasket%201975">1975</a>, and <a href="EuroBasket%201977">1977</a>, followed by two more consecutive ones in <a href="EuroBasket%201989">1989</a> and <a href="EuroBasket%201991">1991</a>). As a result of the 1970 FIBA World Championship win, basketball experienced a significant surge of popularity throughout the country, leading to the authorities initiating construction of a number of indoor sporting facilities. Some of the arenas built during this period include: Zagreb's <a href="Dom%20Sportova">Dom Sportova</a> (1972), Belgrade's <a href="Hala%20Pionir">Hala Pionir</a> (1973), <a href="Sportska%20dvorana%20Baldekin">Baldekin Sports Hall</a> in <a href="%C5%A0ibenik">Šibenik</a> (1973), <a href="Dvorana%20Mladosti">Dvorana Mladosti</a> in <a href="Rijeka">Rijeka</a> (1973), <a href="Hala%20Pinki">Hala Pinki</a> in the Belgrade municipality of <a href="Zemun">Zemun</a> (1974), <a href="%C4%8Cair%20Sports%20Center">Čair Sports Center</a> in <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a> (1974), Kragujevac's <a href="Hala%20Jezero">Hala Jezero</a> (1978), <a href="Mora%C4%8Da%20Sports%20Center">Morača Sports Center</a> in <a href="Titograd">Titograd</a> (1978), <a href="Arena%20Gripe">Gripe Sports Centre</a> in Split (1979), etc.
Simultaneously, on the club level, a multi-tier league system was established in 1945 with the <a href="First%20Federal%20Basketball%20League">First Federal League</a> at the top of the pyramid. Initially played outdoors—on concrete and clay surfaces—and contested from early spring until mid autumn within the same calendar year due to weather constraints, <a href="1967%E2%80%9368%20Yugoslav%20First%20Basketball%20League">league games began to be played indoors</a> from October 1967 despite the country still lacking appropriate infrastructure. Initially played in makeshift fair halls and industrial warehouses, club basketball in Yugoslavia experienced a significant organizational upgrade following the 1970 FIBA World Championship win with the country's Communist authorities authorizing construction of dozens of indoor sporting arenas around the country so that many clubs found permanent homes. Yugoslav clubs won the <a href="Euroleague">European Champion's Cup</a>, the continent's premiere basketball club competition, on seven occasions—<a href="KK%20Bosna">KK Bosna</a> in <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup">1979</a>, <a href="KK%20Cibona">KK Cibona</a> in <a href="1985%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup%20Final">1985</a> and <a href="1986%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup%20Final">1986</a>, <a href="KK%20Split">Jugoplastika Split</a> in <a href="1989%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup%20Final%20Four">1989</a>, <a href="1990%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup%20Final%20Four">1990</a>, and <a href="1991%20FIBA%20European%20Champions%20Cup%20Final%20Four">1991</a>, and <a href="KK%20Partizan">KK Partizan</a> in <a href="1992%20FIBA%20European%20League%20Final%20Four">1992</a>.
Notable players included <a href="Radivoj%20Kora%C4%87">Radivoj Korać</a>, <a href="Ivo%20Daneu">Ivo Daneu</a>, <a href="Kre%C5%A1imir%20%C4%86osi%C4%87">Krešimir Ćosić</a>, <a href="Zoran%20Slavni%C4%87">Zoran Slavnić</a>, <a href="Dra%C5%BEen%20Dalipagi%C4%87">Dražen Dalipagić</a>, <a href="Dragan%20Ki%C4%87anovi%C4%87">Dragan Kićanović</a>, <a href="Mirza%20Deliba%C5%A1i%C4%87">Mirza Delibašić</a>, <a href="Dra%C5%BEen%20Petrovi%C4%87">Dražen Petrović</a>, <a href="Vlade%20Divac">Vlade Divac</a>, <a href="Dino%20Ra%C4%91a">Dino Rađa</a>, <a href="Toni%20Kuko%C4%8D">Toni Kukoč</a>, and <a href="%C5%BDarko%20Paspalj">Žarko Paspalj</a>.
Water polo.
Water polo is another sport with strong heritage in the era that predates the creation of Communist Yugoslavia. Throughout the 1950s and early 1960s, the Yugoslav national team had always been a contender, but never quite managed to make the final step. It was in the 1968 Olympics that the generation led by <a href="Mirko%20Sandi%C4%87">Mirko Sandić</a> and <a href="Ozren%20Bona%C4%8Di%C4%87">Ozren Bonačić</a> finally got the gold, beating Soviet Union after extra time. The country won two more Olympic golds – in 1984 and 1988. It also won two World Championship titles – in 1986 and 1991, the latter coming without Croatian players who by that time had already left the national team. And finally the team won only one European Championship title, in 1991, after failing to do so for previous 40 years during which it always finished second or third. The 1980s and early 1990s were the golden age for Yugoslav water polo during which players such as <a href="Igor%20Milanovi%C4%87">Igor Milanović</a>, <a href="Perica%20Buki%C4%87">Perica Bukić</a>, <a href="Veselin%20%C4%90uho">Veselin Đuho</a>, <a href="Deni%20Lu%C5%A1i%C4%87">Deni Lušić</a>, <a href="Dubravko%20%C5%A0imenc">Dubravko Šimenc</a>, Milorad Krivokapić, <a href="Aleksandar%20%C5%A0o%C5%A1tar">Aleksandar Šoštar</a>, etc. established themselves as the best in the world.
Handball.
Yugoslavia won two Olympic gold medals – <a href="Handball%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972</a> in Munich (handball returned as an Olympic sport following a 36-year absence) and <a href="Handball%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984</a> in Los Angeles. The country also won the <a href="World%20Men%27s%20Handball%20Championship">World Championships</a> title in <a href="1986%20World%20Men%27s%20Handball%20Championship">1986</a>. SFR Yugoslavia never got to compete at the <a href="European%20Men%27s%20Handball%20Championship">European Championship</a> because the competition got established in 1994. <a href="Veselin%20Vujovi%C4%87">Veselin Vujović</a> was voted <a href="IHF%20World%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">World Player of the Year</a> in 1988 (first time the vote was held) by <a href="International%20Handball%20Federation">IHF</a>. Other notable players over the years included <a href="Abaz%20Arslanagi%C4%87">Abaz Arslanagić</a>, <a href="Zoran%20%C5%BDivkovi%C4%87%20%28handballer%29">Zoran "Tuta" Živković</a>, <a href="Branislav%20Pokrajac">Branislav Pokrajac</a>, <a href="Zlatan%20Arnautovi%C4%87">Zlatan Arnautović</a>, <a href="Mirko%20Ba%C5%A1i%C4%87">Mirko Bašić</a>, <a href="Jovica%20Elezovi%C4%87">Jovica Elezović</a>, <a href="Mile%20Isakovi%C4%87">Mile Isaković</a>, etc. On the women's side, the game also yielded some notable results – the women's team won Olympic gold in <a href="Handball%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984</a> while it also won <a href="World%20Women%27s%20Handball%20Championship">World Championship</a> in <a href="1973%20World%20Women%27s%20Handball%20Championship">1973</a>. Just like Veselin Vujović in 1988 on the men's side, <a href="Svetlana%20Kiti%C4%87">Svetlana Kitić</a> was voted the World Player of the Year for the same year. There was great enthusiasm in Yugoslavia when Sarajevo was selected as the site of the <a href="1984%20Winter%20Olympic%20Games">1984 Winter Olympic Games</a>.
Individual sports.
FPR/SFR Yugoslavia also managed to produce a multitude of successful athletes in individual disciplines. Tennis had always been a popular and well-followed sport in the country. Still, due to lack of financial means for tennis infrastructure and support of individual athletes, the participation rates among the Yugoslav youngsters for tennis were always low compared to other sports. All this meant that talented players determined to make it to pro level mostly had to rely on their own families rather than the country's tennis federation. Yugoslav players still managed to produce some notable results, mostly in the women's game. In <a href="1977%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20Singles">1977</a>, the country got its first <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28tennis%29">Grand Slam</a> champion when clay court specialist <a href="Mima%20Jau%C5%A1ovec">Mima Jaušovec</a> won at <a href="French%20Open">Roland Garros</a>, beating <a href="Floren%C8%9Ba%20Mihai">Florența Mihai</a>; Jaušovec reached two more French Open finals (in <a href="1978%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20Singles">1978</a> and <a href="1983%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20Singles">1983</a>), but lost both of them. It was with the rise of teenage phenom <a href="Monica%20Seles">Monica Seles</a> during early 1990s that the country became a powerhouse in female tennis: she won five Grand slam events under the flag of SFR Yugoslavia – two French Opens, two Australian Opens, and one US Open. She went on to win three more Grand Slam titles under the flag of FR Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro) as well as yet one more Grand Slam after immigration to the United States. In men's tennis, Yugoslavia never produced a Grand Slam champion, though it had two finalists. In <a href="1970%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">1970</a>, <a href="%C5%BDeljko%20Franulovi%C4%87">Željko Franulović</a> reached the French Open final, losing to <a href="Jan%20Kode%C5%A1">Jan Kodeš</a>. Three years later, in <a href="1973%20French%20Open%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20Singles">1973</a>, <a href="Nikola%20Pili%C4%87">Nikola Pilić</a> also reached the French Open final, but lost it to <a href="Ilie%20N%C4%83stase">Ilie Năstase</a>. Skiers have been very successful in World Cup competitions and the Olympics (Bojan Križaj, Jure Franko, Boris Strel, Mateja Svet). Winter-spots had a special boost during the <a href="1984%20Winter%20Olympics">1984 Winter Olympics</a> held in Sarajevo. Gymnast <a href="Miroslav%20Cerar">Miroslav Cerar</a> won a number of accolades, including two Olympic gold medals during the early 1960s. During the 1970s a pair of Yugoslav boxers, heavyweight <a href="Mate%20Parlov">Mate Parlov</a> and welterweight <a href="Marijan%20Bene%C5%A1">Marijan Beneš</a>, won multiple championships. During the late 1970s and into the 1980s, their results were matched by heavyweight <a href="Slobodan%20Ka%C4%8Dar">Slobodan Kačar</a>. For many years, Yugoslavia was considered the second strongest "chess" nation in the world after the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. Arguably the biggest name in Yugoslav chess was <a href="Svetozar%20Gligori%C4%87">Svetozar Gligorić</a>, who played in three <a href="Candidates%20Tournament">Candidates Tournament</a>s between 1953 and 1968 and in 1958 won the <a href="Golden%20Badge">Golden Badge</a> as the best athlete in Yugoslavia.
National anthem.
Yugoslavia and Poland shared the melody of its national anthem. Its first lyrics were written in 1834 under the title <a href="Hey%2C%20Slavs">"Hey, Slavs" ("Hej, Sloveni")</a> and it has since served as the anthem of the <a href="Pan-Slavism">Pan-Slavic movement</a>, the anthem of the <a href="Sokol">Sokol</a> physical education and political movement, and the anthem of the World War II-era Slovak Republic, Yugoslavia, and Serbia and Montenegro. The song is also considered to be the second, unofficial anthem of the Slovaks. Its melody is based on "Mazurek Dąbrowskiego", which has been also the anthem of Poland since 1926, but it is much slower and more accentuated.

Remembrance of the time of the joint state and its perceived positive attributes is referred to as <a href="Yugo-nostalgia">Yugo-nostalgia</a>. People who identify with the former Yugoslav state may self-identify as <a href="Yugoslavs">Yugoslavs</a>. All of the successor states are or were candidates for <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> membership, with Slovenia and Croatia being the two who have already joined the union. <a href="Accession%20of%20Slovenia%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Slovenia joined in 2004</a>, and <a href="Accession%20of%20Croatia%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Croatia followed in 2013</a>. <a href="Accession%20of%20North%20Macedonia%20to%20the%20European%20Union">North Macedonia</a>, <a href="Accession%20of%20Montenegro%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Montenegro</a> and <a href="Accession%20of%20Serbia%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Serbia</a> are official candidates. <a href="Accession%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> has submitted an application and <a href="Accession%20of%20Kosovo%20to%20the%20European%20Union">Kosovo</a> has not submitted an application but is recognized as a potential candidate for a possible <a href="future%20enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">future enlargement of the European Union</a>. All states of the former Yugoslavia, with the exception of Kosovo, have subscribed to the <a href="Stabilisation%20and%20Association%20Process">Stabilisation and Association Process</a> with the EU. <a href="European%20Union%20Rule%20of%20Law%20Mission%20in%20Kosovo">European Union Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo</a> is a deployment of EU police and civilian resources to Kosovo in an attempt to restore <a href="Kosovo%23Law">rule of law</a> and combat the widespread <a href="Crime%20in%20Kosovo">organized crime</a>. This is mostly due to <a href="emigration">emigration</a>, which intensified during and after the Yugoslav Wars, during the 1990s to 2000s, but also due to low birth rates. Close to 120,000 <a href="Yugoslav%20Americans">refugees from the former Yugoslavia</a> were registered in the United States from 1991 to 2002, and 67,000 <a href="Yugoslav%20Canadian">migrants from the former Yugoslavia</a> were registered in Canada between 1991 and 2001.
